39375947.review:
Мне понравилась. Необычный геймплей, три раза меняющий форму. Как будто в разные игры играешь. Редактор уровней вообще очень удивил --- нечасто игра делает такой Inception. Не буду спойлерить лишнего.

Очень много явных рассуждений и глубоких мыслей, скрытых в обрывках разговоров и аудиозаписях, которые находишь в процессе игры. Претенциозно и скорее всего должно было быть очень захватывающе для тех, кому интересно, но меня вообще не заинтересовали все эти подковёрные игры. Запороли разработку игры, да и пёс с вами. Кто там с кем флиртовал и на кого зуб имел, неинтересно совершенно.

Скорость ходьбы очень низкая для игры с таким количеством бэктрекинга и таким нарочито плохо сделанным миром. Ладно хоть быстрая телепортация есть.

Для того, чтобы получить все ачивки, эту игру нужно пройти два раза, а replayability здесь практически на нуле. Первый акт, который вроде как пролог, вообще очень нудно проходить по второму разу. Да и по первому тоже.

Короче, спорные решения портят общее впечатление от игры, но идея мне очень понравилась. И за фишку с редактором уровней и сюжетом, с ним связанным, я прощаю почти всё.

39211434.review:
Топчик! Брать, играть, обозревать! 
Это как раз тот случай, когда все друзья скупают разпиаренный шлак, а этой игры ни у кого нет. Да у меня и самого руки не сразу дошли до нее, каюсь и жалею.

Я боюсь сказать что-то лишнее, поскольку будут сплошняком спойлеры.
Игра представляет из себя изображение игры-долгостроя. 
Вы почувствуете себя если не богом, то хотя бы настоящим волшебником, который созидает, хоть и назло другим. И вот когда ты уже прошарил все фишки, хочется дальше лазать по билдам и воротить свою уличную магию, сюжет круто поворачивает и открывает на голову больше возможностей!

В качестве симулятора геймдева сойдет.

39183188.review: A very interesting thing with genuinely unique ideas and mechanics. The setup is that you're an unnamed playtester on a game that's been stuck in development hell for years. You end up with 'debug' powers in the game world and need to use these to progress, while playing witness to the squabbling between the major actors in the game's development; which gives you an insight into the painful history of it all. This setup is used to good effect right from the beginning (e.g. you spawn and pick up the sort of legendary sword you'd expect in such circumstances and then it's almost instantly wrenched from your grasp by the lead designer after an argument about whether the game should even have any combat or not) and all throughout we get skewerings of familiar concepts like crowd-funding, ridiculous fan demands, etc. Mechanically though it's also very interesting and well put together. Your debug powers don't extend to changing anything about your own avatar; but what you can do is trap and edit the attributes of all NPCs in the game. This is handled through a toggling interface rather than actual code cutting but the upshot is that all the behaviours and armaments of the objects you encounter can be tweaked and buffed, with the caveat that you can only use things you've already encountered. Want to create an army of hovering attack dogs that use the fire-proof properties of rocks and will attack mushrooms on sight? Have at it! This leads to a sandbox-y approach to problem solving and the games makes experimentation suitably easy so you never fear just dicking around. If I had any complaint it would be that there's just not enough of this and it seems to end just as you're properly motoring with it all. Oh, and there's one attack type which is almost game-breakingly powerful once you work out how it functions. The upside to that is the game never outstays it's welcome and I think most people here would get a lot of fun out of this 'game about making games'.

New-Player-Game-Ruining Spoiler Gush Section:
[spoiler]For real, don’t read this if you haven’t finished the game. 
This is just me getting ideas out of my head off in a corner of steam, where no one will see them.
-
I played the demo for this, like, 2 years ago and the game had been sitting in my wishlist for a looong time. My discrepancy towards buying it was my crap-laptop; hindering great games with a burnt-out GPU never felt good. I bumping into it again this year, with a new computer, and the demo had retained its impact on me. So during the Steam Sale I caved, and I sure am glad I did.

What an interesting concept! How do you make an unplayable game playable? By making a new set of rules that break everything? But what if we made that unplayable game’s new playability was structured but it still felt like you were a rough element in this hopeless game?
The way you go from playing their game, to utilizing their game to overthrow control of their game to remaking their game for them, all while using the features you’ve learned, was astonishing!

The tangibility of the reward for higher completion being the genuinely fun game creating stage is a phenomenal idea! You’ve played the tutorial, you’ve learned our game, now let’s see what you can do. It’s not a perfect system, but it still captured my imagination. It’d be great to go 100% the overworld and come back to finish my 8/10 episode with all sorts of bosses, allies and cheeky signs.

Character and voice acting were terrific. There's also some really decent story/ideas hidden in the game that give you a lot to think about.

Anyways, I’m off to go trick all my friends into playing the demo. :)
[/spoiler]

My full review is [url=https://davidyat.es/2016/10/09/review-the-magic-circle/]here[/url].

In brief: Interesting both for its meta "game about games" content and ingenious central mechanic. Anyone who enjoyed [i]The Stanley Parable[/i] or [i]The Beginner’s Guide[/i] should definitely play this, and I’d also recommend it to fans of first-person puzzle games like [i]Portal[/i].

On the other hand, if you’re really upset by pixellated graphics, ugly monospaced fonts and deliberately unfinished and sloppy aesthetics in general, or can’t stand games with sub-five-hour playtimes, this may be one to skip.

38749950.review:
I like and dislike this game at the same time, and for the same reason. On one hand, I enjoy how it tells a side of story that's never been told before; on the other hand, I am tired of the amount of self-aware commentary games that sort of exploded after Stanley Parable.

Magic Circle, like many of its kind, has the entire game built around this one novelty. But without a refined, tried-and-true machenics to back it up, it only takes a few games before novelty become cliche. Look past all the little narrative tricks, what's left is a very boring game in a ugly, poorly made world. (Though it's very convenient that a poorly made world sort of fit its plot.)

38706230.review:
A short and sweet game poking fun at game development, yet also showing the behind the scenes details that people often miss.
Pretty sure "Ish" is supposed to be a reference to Peter Molyneux, seeing as they're both wash up has beens ;)
And I'm pretty sure I heard a guard whistling the guard whistle from Fable... sooo....

The List:
+An interesting concept for a game that makes you feel like you have a lot of freedom, while mostly being an illusion on that (which ties in to the central theme)
+Ish is a twat, but you can't help but atleast understand the things he went through and feel sorry for him, so good character writing.
+Companion character/narrator is gold
+Central theme of control and powerlessness
+Game gets reallllyy real when Ish does his speech
+Varying mechanics that makes the game incredibly convincing.
-Short
-The meat of the game is a bit lean
+The meat is tasty though.
-The search bar easter eggs didn't include a reference to Old Pro, Or atleast it wasn't easy to find if it existed.
-Coda sucks at playing my game and kept dying half way through >:( Coda sucks at video games confirmed.
-There were some indiscrepencies in the game, such as missing objects and areas you could see through into the void, while this made SENSE in the game and could be argued could have been put there intentionally, I don't see that as an excuse.
-Flight was always a helicopter rotor. While other options often held originality and changed to fight different models, this one lacked it. Even Float with it's constant clouds changed things up with different poses.
-I'm not one to argue with developers about the price of their games, because it's their decision what their game is worth. But I don't consider the 5 hours I put into this worth the full price of $20

This weirdly immersive and original experience might not be one I'll forget, but I don't think I'd be replaying it anytime soon.
The lack of value for game time; however, makes its full asking price something that feels harsh, rather than fair.
8/10 (which is ironically enough, the score Old Pro gave me first time I got him to review a level... until I retried it until he said 10/10...)

38253097.review:
I'm surprised that the first time I heard about this game was from going through the back catalog of a video game podcast. Maybe it didn't really get talked about or maybe I just missed all of it, but regardless, The Magic Circle is a very fun time.

I won't go too hard into a plot synopsis, that info is available plenty of places if you want it. It's a commentary on game design and development that I think works in multiple ways and is told with a very dry humor that I really enjoyed.

The overall look of the game is very appealing, sort of comic-booky with splashes of color that really stand out. The voice acting is excellent - I was pretty jazzed to hear Rusty Venture. The gameplay is really excellent - you can't really do anything yourself, you have to freeze and edit enemies so that they become your allies instead of fighting you, and you can also take their abilities (down to fighting and walking) and give them to other creatures. I did find that the puzzles in the game didn't really match the complexity of such a powerful tool - there's pretty much only three creatures in the game that have abilities I'd say you need, and you might be able to work around two of those; in addition there are creature upgrades you can find but I never used any of them or felt like anything would have been significantly easier with them.

When you're given the chance to design your own level and are given more resources based on how well you explored the overworld, I thought that was actually a lot more fun than I expected, and I had a really good time listening to a couple of the characters play through it and comment on how it was put together.

Overall, don't miss this one.

A játék első fele a felfedezéssel és a gyűjtögetéssel még egy kicsit nehézkes (sokat segít benne a térkép ("M")), ezért nekem a másik fele tetszett jobban, a "játék" összekontárkodása. Rövid, de ötletes, és mind a játékokról, mind a készítőiről, mind a játékosokról vannak benne érdekes gondolatok.

38000952.review: Control is a little janky, and first person floating menu navigation is inelegant, but there are a few neat puzzles, unique gameplay elements, and a dramatic, darkly-comedic story.  James Urbaniak's voice acting (also known for Dr. Venture) was a big highlight for me.

37855195.review:
It's been a while since I've played this game, and I'm trying to write this review from memory.

This game is great. At its core, this game is a "metroidvania"-style puzzle game. As you progress, you unlock new abilities which you can then use in areas you already visited to unlock secrets (among other things). The level design itself involves a lot of interconnected areas not unlike Dark Souls. Different areas seem to come from different eras of game design, which gives most areas a unique feel to them.

The narrative is pretty interesting. You are inside of a video game that has been through development hell, and you are supposed to help finish it. Along the way you learn exactly what the developers have been through trying to finish the game themselves.

37567244.review:
[h1][b]Lo inesperado[/b][/h1]

[b]The Magic Circle[/b] es uno de esos juegos que cuando alguien te pregunta [i]¿de qué va?[/i] te quedas mirando paticueto al que te ha formulado la cuestión. A lo que más se acerca posiblemente es a un [i]walking sim[/i], pero también incorpora algunos combates de forma muy imaginativa, ligeros puzzles y sobre todo mucha inventiva. Es una experiencia distinta: para bien o para mal es difícil que hayas jugado a algo similar.

La clave de este juego dentro del juego es el hackeo: pero no pienses en códigos enrevesados, más bien en ir sustrayendo y añadiendo características clave de las criaturas con las que te vas cruzando para poder proseguir. Y la forma de tirar adelante es muy imaginativa, de forma que el avance se puede realizar de muchas formas distintas para alcanzar el mismo objetivo, explorando un mundo no muy grande pero sí muy libre, mientras se te va planteando la historia de cómo se ha gestado este juego y los intereses ocultos detrás de él.

La recta final es como mínimo desconcertante y extraña, y después de "terminar" el juego podrás quedarte todavía creando en ¿modo dios? O lo que vendría ser el programador jefe, vamos.

Una comedia enrevesada sobre los entresijos de la industria, las expectativas de los fans frente a las desarrolladoras y las aspiraciones últimas de los creadores. No es un cambiavidas, pero sí algo diferente y ante todo, inesperado.

37551002.review: It's so weird, but it works so well

37438816.review: A quite fun and funny meta-riff on games in the vein of The Stanley Parable, though more interested in satirizing the industry than the games themselves, paired with a unique gameplay mechanic that gives tons of potential tools to solve problems, then lets you come up with the solutions yourself rather than trying to jump on to the developer's logic train.  The game even explicitly notes that if it feels like you're cheating or exploiting the mechanics of the game, then you're playing correctly.  Definitely worth your time and money.

37436007.review: Magic Circle is odd. It's almost like a programming game, but a programming game is the player lining up a bunch of elements in a particular order so they produce a desired result. This is more like you play by figuring out which elements to throw together into a pile in hopes that they combine to form the game you want. It's kind of a sandbox? Running around getting all the pieces you need, can be done in whatever order, but some parts are easier if you do them after others. And the final boss fight is a complete and total genre change from the rest of the game. But it somehow manages to all work together, not even "in spite of itself" kind of work together, it just works.

Decir que adquirí el juego en rebajas por que lo ví en un analisis y me llamó la atención.
No me eperaba una narrativa así en este juego tal y como me lo habían planteado. TMC sabe como llamar la atención de un jugador curioso ("con alma de teaster") y que aprecia un buen juego. Secretos más allá del mapeado, trama, subtrama, etc. Es un juego de narrativa, aunque acabes haciendo algo complpetamente distinto a lo que estabas jugando. No esperes ación. El sistema de combate es muy curioso pero casi nulo, puedes pasear a tus anchas y los puzzles no te partirán la cabeza. Se termina en un par de horas, muchas más si pretendes el 100%. Eso no quita que esté ¡RECOMENDADÍSIMO!

Después del 100%... nada. Pero es lo que tiene un juego de narrativa intensa, al igual que un libro: cuando te lo terminas, te lo puedes volver a leer si eso, pero queda en la biblioteca. Sí, pero muy satisfecho de ello.
(Aún así, compradlo en rebajas; no creo que deba valer 5 euros, pero tampoco creo que 20 sea lo que yo pagaría por las horas y experiencia que me ofrece).

36335806.review:
Where the heck do I even start..

Usually milking the meta outlook on video games is mostly overused, but since this is the core foundation of the game itself, there isn't much avoiding it. Though, as your main goal is to go beyond the 4th wall and angrily take control of vaporware, you feel much more powerful than the game implies. 

The Magic Circle is a very fun experience that highlights and teaches the key elements to creating a video game, while you play the video game... about making a video game. There isn't some overarching difficulty to the game, just your own creativity being utilized to work towards a goal. Simulating the ability to remove and create different arguments for game elements is a very interactive mechanic that allows for creative freedom. Good game.

This game really is quite great. It has that self-aware "game within a game" aspect to it.
The puzzles take the form of "hacking" the game to be able to bypass obstacles, and to just make things work the way you want them to.
The Magic Circle has a great story to tell, and feeling like you're a part of it as you make your way through broken and unfinished (all intentional of course) you start to feel a sense of personal responsibility / ownership to see how things go.
It's a great journey, and more people should check it out!

35141671.review:
'The Magic Circle' a skill juggling puzzle game with light strategy elements, its key focus being a satirical look at the games industry. The developers, the fans, the players. As well as that, the game presents what feels like a quite genuine examination of why art is made, not only that, but the unhealthy practices and mental gymnastics that develop in an undeveloped artist. That, along with the way in which the game (which is primarily dark comedy satire) manages to hold up a very engaging narrative and multiple sub plots, all within the space of 3 hours, and do it all really well, was extremely surprising. I went into the game for some laughs and some interesting mechanics and came out of it having experienced a very rich and surprising narrative as well, I don't want to say too much, because I think some of the turns the plots take are worth just experiencing. That mess of words up the top "skill juggling puzzle game with light strategy elements" is the easiest way I can describe what is and develops into throughout the game, a very well designed set of mechanics that seamlessly work and compliment one another and the narrative. The mechanics manage to be deep, story driven, highly based on player agency and choice, satisfying and most of all fun.
Its been a while since I've played a game that so well hits its marks!
Really awesome, highly recommend people check it out!

(p.s. I do really need to go through it again because I can feel the ideas and concepts that it presented getting away from me, but more than anything, I'd say thats some evidence of how well constructed it is...in a way)

35023653.review:
The Magic Circle, is a strange game.
You play a game within a game, and experience the story of the game’s development and its founder while moving through the world, cutting it up and stitching it together again as you see fit, by pulling properties out of objects and forcing them into others e.g. changing a mushroom to attack enemies with a railgun.

Pros:
* Unique setting and story
* The cut and paste mechanic is pretty cool
* There is no “right” way to solve most puzzles, you can make your own

Cons:
* The “unfinished” graphics style probably isn’t for everyone.

Recommendation:
If you like games that are a bit strange or experimental, such as e.g. Evoland, you will probably like this as well, and I’d recommend buying now.
Otherwise I’d recommend buying it on sale and try it out anyway.

34757584.review:
The Magic Circle

A small game that's hard to draw a comparison to. The closest games I could maybe use to compare might be either the Stanley Parable's knack for a clever narrator, or Portal's puzzle solving and succinct writing, or even Pony Island's tendency to play with the fourth wall in order to progress.

Anyways, the story goes that you are a 'tester' for an indie fantasy RPG game about to be released called The Magic Circle, but of course the game is nowhere near completion, which is where you come in.

Saying too much would be spoilers, but the short version of it is that in order to progress through the game, you have to take advantage of mod powers to wander the incomplete landscape. Once an enemy is trapped or defeated, you may edit its properties, including setting it as an ally to you, switching out its mode of combat, or granting it special acquired properties.

These special properties are your items. Your inventory does not have alchemy ingredients or quest items, rather you collect properties. Coming up on an enemy or object lets you rob it of special abilities, which are stored in your inventory until you are ready to give it to an ally to solve puzzles or defeat enemies. Puzzles are very open-ended, and rarely have a single way of completing them; use what you know about the properties you have to dig further into the world, until you find a combination of powers that will let you accomplish the game's ultimate goal: getting dev powers.

Overall, it's a short but clever little game that is great for an evening's romp.

Mais un gamer coincé dans une vielle bêta intervient et nous apprend à faire des modifications dans le code ni vu ni connu, il nous apprend à "hacker" les ennemis pour s'en faire des alliés que l'on pourra ensuite modifier à volonté en leur injectant du code récupéré sur différents ennemis.

Une aventure de 4-5h que j'ai plutôt apprécié. Je ne la recommanderai pas forcément à tout le monde, il faut avoir le courage de s'aventurer sur les territoires un peu extrêmes, mais ca aura été une expérience intéressante, drôle et qui permet d'explorer l'envers du décor. 34715803.review:
The central discussion in [i] The Magic Circle [/i] isn't something I think fit for a Steam review, nor myself exactly capable of it. Even after playing it, it sticks out as a game that does not want to succeed as such: it functions best as a metanarrative on the experience of play, and the responsibilities and capacities of creators and consumers in the modern space. That's probably a suicidal shtick, but if you enjoy narrative-experiential walking simulators such as [i] The Beginner's Guide [/i] and vacuously unfunny alternative universe Crows, Crows, Crows titles, (Dr. Langeskov...) maybe it'll do something for you. It's advertising itself as a 'darkly comedic story,' but I disagree: I smirked a few times, and that's about it. 

The game seems to lose sight of its narrative ambitions at times, lost amongst some less-than-ideal play systems. Mostly trial and error puzzles, of which there are few, a functional collectathon that rewards world building texts and audio logs (which [i] interrupt [/i] your adventuring in order to be played), and shallow power acquisition. [b] But that's the point,[/b] the game insists: you're walking around an incomplete indie-funded mess, a receptacle of consumer's hopes and designer's difficulties. And against this I rattle that neither parody nor self-awareness preserve a game's systems, and by the end of the relatively brief adventure (~2-3 hours), The Circle has a response for me: I'm entitled in this perspective. Yeah, well, maybe I am. 

I was sufficiently enraptured by the story to see it through to the end. I think the game's division of achievements behind sub-par game systems (such as waiting for audiologs, and collectathonning in a bland world), as well as playthrough-exclusive achievements amidst a twist-dependant narrative, is stupid: but my criticisms of its systems melt away with claims of intentionality. I'll say, if nothing else, it's worth experiencing for the thoughts it provokes towards the end: the cans of which should've been opened a few hours earlier, and with greater consideration of the idea than an extended monologue.

I remember hearing about this through Jim Sterling a long while back and have had it in my wishlist since then. I finally got around to playing it, and... whoa.
The game itself is guenuly interesting, and has quite and interesting romp throughout. Being able to trap and alter monsters to help you in overcoming challenges is quite a nice feat. It also adds a puzzle element to the game, as you will need to use your creatures to overcome certain challenges. Such as finding an entity with Flameproof to fight the active Flammers. Once you manage to take control of one of the "Sky Bastards", you'll be finding yourself in a game making room, as you try to make dungeons for Pro and your fans to play through. As a game dev hopefully, I honestly like this, even if I think more depth could've been put into it. Still, it is a bit of fun to get through, and the story does do a good job of showing how easily ideas get thrown around and scrapped.
I do have a couple complants: the backtracking in the overworld can get incredibly tedious, especally when Life becomes and issue. Warping helps, but only by so much. The other complant is that the mouse sensitivity is WAY to high. I'd recommend turning it down before playing, otherwise your screen will zip right by.
Overall, I give this a very positive review.

34281349.review:
7/10

The Magic Circle is a satirical, first-person exploration game. You play as a playtester, exploring an unfinished game that has been repeatedly scrapped in various phases of development. By befriending an in-game entity, you learn to manipulate the environment and creatures within the game, to learn more about the developers and history of the title.

This core of the gameplay is fascinating, locating creatures and swapping properties in and out like a mad scientist. You will often need to locate a particular creature to steal its ability in order to progress or defeat a tough enemy. In some ways it is a creative puzzle game. Often, the combinations you create are hilarious. As an added bonus, you can name your new creations (what would you like to call your flying dog with a railgun for a mouth?).

If the game were limited in scope to only focus on this core, it would likely be a better game. However, there is another plot, a conflict between the developers, that I found less intriguing. Though this culminates in a very entertaining scene, I still felt that the title would have been better without it. The game attempts to make an argument about "ownership" when players begin to feel they have a better understanding of the game world than its initial creator (think if viewers decided that certain aspects of a new Game of Thrones book were inappropriate, and wrested control of writing and publication from George RR Martin). I can't say that the attempt falls completely flat, but I will say that The Beginner's Guide does a much better job exploring this theme.

However, the gameplay in the Beginner's Guide is nowhere near as engaging as the Magic Circle. It's worth a play if you'd like to try a puzzle game that's quite different than most, but I can't say that it provided any new or grand insights to me on game development.

I didn't like this game much.  The writing is good, and the voice acting is good.  Other than that it's almost "walking simulator" levels of boring.  It's incredibly slow-paced, too short, and actually too story-heavy if that's possible.  There's minimal combat, no real NPCs to interact with, and no actual choices in the gameplay - despite the seemingly open world, it's basically a railroad from start to finish.

As for the graphics and look of the game, I understand WHY they made it look like a hot bag of crap, but that doesn't change the fact that it looks like a hot bag of crap.  It's uglier than Fallout 3, and that's really saying something.  But that made it SO unpleasant to look at that I didn't want to play it.

34083973.review:
A very good game that takes the walking sim and turns it into an eclectic puzzler. You use various abilities stripped from mobs to turn other mobs to help you. It takes some out of the box thinking and there are no single solutions to any challenge. 

However, the game is definately a casual experience. There is no challenge that will test you beyond your witt or patience. There is combat, but you are not directly involved. 

There is a story here as well. It's a meta commentary on a meta game, where you play as the 4th wall inserting your own version of meta as you progess... Yup, it's an interesting concept. As it plays out however, there are some weak points. Nothing that ruins anything, but don't expect an epic story like Firewatch or Valley. 

Where this game suffers is in level design. The game is slightly open-world. As you play you open new parts of the level. However, they weave into each other. Parts show up on top of other parts. It can get difficult to track where you have and have not been. But it's not so difficult that you'll ever get completely lost. I found it a bit annoying at times, but never to the point of frustration.

Achievements in this game are fair yet not easy to 100%. Expect to play the game at least twice if you're achievement hunting. I played till the end and found out I missed a decent portion of collectibles. I may keep this game install for a rainy day when I feel like going in for 100%, but for now, I personally feel satisfied with the game.

Overall, The Magic Cirlce is an enjoyable game. It's got enough going for it to keep most people captivated until the end (6 to 8hrs). Definately recommended by me!

33394699.review:
Very cute--it struck me such that I feel like I'm indebted to review it, [spoiler]now that I own it.[/spoiler]

Without giving anything away, this is a shortish, enjoyable game with a unique 'combat' system and some unusually meta storytelling. Not [i]too[/i] meta--never gets preachy or up on a quirky high-horse. Treats players like they have a functioning, analytical brain at all times. Low stress gameplay, just a fun ride through a weird world, spying on some devs with problems. Beaten in 4 hours according to Steam, progressing at a tempered pace. I haven't done so yet, but in about 10 hours one could 100% it (following guides, at least).


 [b]Pros:[/b]
- Fufillment from aquiring an increasing number of combat abilities.
- Exploration, with rewards for your time.
- Encouraged player-driven comedy, regarding the 'combat' options & some other segments.
- Good comedy overall. Appropriate and funny. Game made me smirk a lot.
- Challenges/puzzles that are not hard to understand, but might be difficult to overcome. [spoiler]The fire puzzle can kiss my a**, I finally flew over it. [/spoiler]
- Interesting characters, plot-driven. Unfortunately, relatable, especially if you've been keeping up with game-o-sphere happenings.
- Has some nice personal touches. You become a character yourself, and unlike most similar games, I felt like I really was.
- Fosters suspence-of-disbelief very well. I'm still impressed at the glitch execution--most glitch or crash motifs are done sloppily and feel obviously fake. With few exceptions, simulated game failures felt like they were actually happening, at least before my brain caught up with what was happening. [spoiler] I'm especially sensitive to this kind of stuff--serious props for finally not making me cringe or flip my keyboard in disgust. In fact, it's what drew me in to buy the game in the first place! [/spoiler]
- [b]Some seriously cool usages of the meta narrative.[/b] I don't want to spoil any of them because they are the highpoint of the game, and what it does best. In a sentence, the [spoiler] real [/spoiler] devs really utilize the game's setting.
- High-quality voice acting. Seriously, a great cast who convey whatever his character's personality is. [spoiler]Hearing Dr. Venture was a little distracting, but not unwelcome. What's with James and playing megalomanial blue disembodied eyes in videogames? [/spoiler]
- Doesn't pull punches? I'm not sure how to explain this, but for a laid-back game...I found myself listening to dialogue, thinking of something darker/angrier, and then being surprised when the characters actually said that same thing. Pleasantly surprised. Made the characters feel more like real people.
- Nonlinear, somewhat. You choose what you do first, how you do it...a sense of choice/planning goes into what you do.
- Kinda nihilistic without being drab or repulsive.
- Themes about facets of gaming that too few people fully understand/sympathise with, IMO.

 [b]Cons:[/b]
- Bit of an annoying opening, or--it was too predictable. It's not long though, and does serve a purpose.
- I found the plot surprisingly confusing--I'm sure it was told to me, but a lot of required information passes by very quickly. It's all easy to tune out, even the extra audiolog-style reward snippets. Sometimes hard to tell what plot is critical, and what is comedy.
- Depending on how you play, game can be frusturating. There is basically one sequence of abilities one must gain to progress--if the player reaches an impass too many times in a row, it can be a turnoff. Literally--I turned the game off for a week. sorry pro.
- Speaking of breaks, don't take too many. Game is best played in as few sessions as possible, so that one doesn't forget the story/objectives[spoiler], or fail to take a hint [/spoiler]. I came back to my second session a little disoriented. This isn't exactly a 'con,' unless a player is really busy irl or frequently switches games.
- I wasn't aware that one could summon all friendlies or the map until I was nearly at the endgame. There are randomly (?) appearing hint popups which finally led me to the right buttons. Not sure if this was me being a dumb player, or a conveyance issue.
- While exploring, there were too many areas that felt too large given player speed, and a lot of backtracking. While the game isn't bad looking (I found the 2 contrasting styles to be nicely noncomplementary & good visual storytelling), the environments become bland quickly due to the nature of the nonlinear design. [spoiler]The 'create your own' segment kinda sank that in for me. Not that it wasn't really, really cool regardless.[/spoiler] This is especially a problem, because the player often needs to remember specific locations to progress.
- While fun, I found that the core mechanic eroded in a similar way. Too difficult to just do the thing you want to do sometimes.


I detailed the cons more than the pros, but overall they don't cause much grief unless a player's sensibilities are seriously sensitive to one.

TL;DR, compelling game, please buy it, [spoiler] I need money, [/spoiler] you'll probably enjoy your time. Between the 'combat' system, the humor, the characters, and the well-done effects, you have a good chance at liking something.

I don't like numerical ranks, but if you forced me to give you a rating, I'd go light 7/10.
9/10 on a scale of achieving what it set out to be.

33165042.review:
如果不是看到这么高的评分我是绝对不会打开这样一个游戏的，看看她的标签：
冒险\独立\动作\模拟\策略\剧情丰富
看看截图画面，What the hell？完全不是我的菜。
但禁不住高评分诱惑，无聊的我还是打开了这个游戏。

1、菜单上点击开始，步行模拟？画面空旷的我连空旷恐惧症都犯了，然后两个话痨blahblahblah...What the hell？
然后五分钟不到的时间，一周目通关了？What the hell？
然后出来了一个第三者，又开始不停的blahblahblah...What the hell？

2、点击Pro Mode再次开始游戏（二周目？）
这游戏简直有毒，一旦Pro Mode开始就想把他打穿。
我开始逐渐认识到这个游戏的内涵。
又一个打破第四面墙的，让人会心一笑的作品。
长达十年的beta周期，二十年的老粉丝，充满复杂争斗的制作团队，超级话痨的主创，还有卧底，无辜而愤怒的游戏玩家。
神来之笔就是内置的游戏编辑器，通过编辑游戏里面的怪物和物件来过关，通关历程玩家可以自行发挥创意。
最后还通过玩家的努力大闹发布会，成功的将游戏制作权从无能的（？） 开发者夺了过来。惊不惊喜？
现在我们是Open-Source了！然而结局……意不意外？

3、通关以后进入Create Tool（三周目）。
再一次提升游戏的内涵。
我成了制作者，哈哈！！
然而制作的渣一样的游戏惨不忍睹。
嗯，一个游戏的出品真的不容易，珍惜我们玩的每一个游戏吧。

4、Cast上出现了自己的Steam ID，有一瞬间很感动。一个角色扮演游戏，演职表排名第一位的应该是玩家，不是吗？

32972429.review:
I've got to say, this game hit me in an odd way. It's not a very long experience, and the gameplay isn't particularly challenging. I think I counted maybe two actual puzzles in the whole game, and you as the player don't ever get directly involved in combat. So if you're looking for something with challenging or fun gameplay you might want to look elsewhere. What we're really here for is the story.
You play as a being who finds themselves in a world unfinished by its developers, and are tasked by a mysterious voice to essentially mess with their progress and find ways to screw up their game. Along the way you find little notes and audio logs attesting to a messy 20 year long development process with multiple complete restarts, and which serve to flesh out the world outside your small unfinished game. While the story is very short (I completed it in maybe four hours) it is well written, interestingly told, and overall I found it engaging and fun to participate in.
This is the kind of game for people who were fans of Home Alone. The kind of people who are willing to let gameplay take a back seat to an interesting story.
Or if you want you can pick up a monkey-dog, give it helicopter blades, and make it shoot fire.
7/10, would reccomend.

A clever concept that fell short of its potential. You play as a play tester for an unfinished game. Throughout your gameplay you meet characters that personify the philosophies and constituencies of game culture.

PROS:
* Interesting concept
* Quirky characters and story
* Puzzles could be solved in multiple ways

CONS:
* Gameplay was dull. Although puzzles could be solved in multiple ways, many could be solved using the same strategy. It never really felt challenging or exciting.
* Snarky character dialogue was funny at first, but by the end it was just tiring. Everyone felt wronged and was constantly finger-pointing at the other characters. In the end, I didn't really care what happened to any of them, which was just as well because
* The narrative was very linear. The story seemed at all times to expect the player to pick a side, but in the end it didn't matter because all you could do was side with the characters in the way that was predetermined.

OTHER CONSIDERATIONS:
* Short with no replayability

31551077.review:
TMC is weird. I have to start out any analysis with that fact. It's weird and beautiful and bizarre and lovely.

In many ways, TMC is a first person puzzle game, but beyond that it's also a meta commentary on gaming (development, fandoms, and common traps). I personally love it, both for the intentional mish-mash of art styles and the unique experience that it represents, but it's certainly not for everyone.

PROS:
+very funny
+great plot twists
+well-crafted characters
+interesting mechanics
+fantastic voice acting
+diverse experience

CONS:
+short runtime (~3 hours)
+little traditional gameplay
+few mechanics are fully explored

All told, I think it's a very good game and a great experience, but your mileage may vary. Check out the demo and maybe wait for a sale.

31535681.review:
This game puts me in a frustrating place, because it's a good idea. It's just. So poorly executed. 

Okay, first off. This game is not fun to play. I do not find the gameplay interesting; it's slow-paced and repetitive, and the "puzzles" are all so abstract that you end up with a lot of "was i meant to do that" scenarios. I beat the hiver queen just by getting the mindswap ability and putting it on one of my ally monsters. Maybe the game encourages freedom but that just makes everything feel unrewarding. And the last segment of the game is unrewarding too. One easy, EASY puzzle at the E4 demo, and overdramatic and kind of boring cutscene, and then a slow/repetitive "build your own game segment" that you have to start from the very start every time even if you screw up right near the end. 

The game is also really not that visually impressive. The black and white aesthetic doesn't work and the retro style is, well, intentionally dated. Animations aren't that great and often pretty janky. The "conductor whispers" in the music are cute as first but get tiresome quickly. The voice acting is pretty solid though, I'll give it that, and the small snippets of story hidden away are decently rewarding to find.

Also, the game is like 3.5 or so hours long even if you're poking around a lot and $20. And even then. It feels too long. It feels like a glorified tech demo that they tried to stretch out to a full game. It's just. Ugh. So much potential wasted. Maybe it's meta. I don't know. I don't care.

I wanted to like this game but I just did not enjoy it and I have absolutely no desire to return to it & finish off what I missed. So I really can't recommend it on that basis alone, even ignoring all the other faults.

31526020.review:
Qui ne serait pas perturbé à l'idée d'être réduit à un "héros" de jeu-vidéo? 
Une combinaison complexe de 0 et de 1, mais qu'est-ce-que l'humain sinon de l'information et qu'est-ce-que l'information sinon une combinaison de 0 et de 1 ?

Bref...
Et c'est ainsi qu'avant que vous ne vous prêtiez à utiliser ou ramasser n'importe quoi, des "dieux" apparaissent et vous rappelle à l'ordre.

Des "dieux" ou des usurpateurs ? Finalement l'écart n'est pas si ténu entre les deux...
Mais voilà qu'au moment de palper de la chair binaire avec une épée trouvée par terre, ces "dieux" vous font la morale et modifient votre destin.

Avatar rebelle et curieux, les directives de ces odieux personnages bien que charmants vous intrigueront et vous menerez votre propre enquête.

Ish, maze, coda ? Développeur, narrateur ou stagiaire ou même "dieu"? Qu'importe puisque j'ai le pouvoir d'interagir avec l'ADN de vos créations  et de les retourner contre vous.
Je manipule le 0 et le 1 pour parvenir à toutes mes fins, je suis le nouveau "dieu" qui va vous destituer et comprendre l'envers de l'univers avec l'aide de mon vieux pro, et je vous apprendrai comment engendrer une démo digne de ce nom, non "bugguée".

Les couleurs ne sont pas là mais ce sont vos yeux qui les imagineront, à moins que vous ne décidiez de subir les engeances rémanentes.

De toute beauté, doom-like puzzle ultra-original et parfait!!

Ce jeu est à faire juste après avoir fumé de l'herbe qui fait rire !

Points négatifs : 

- Un jeu qui se veut humoristique mais qui n'est pas drôle
- Les couleurs qui piquent les yeux parfois
- On s'ennuie à chercher la suite de l'aventure
- Rapidement pénible

Points positifs :

- Original graphiquement
- Un jeu indie différent
- La bande-son

Ce puzzle game aventure narratif, à la première personne, décalé et à l'humour bien ciblé (la création d'un jeu) ne m'a pas fait rire, je l'ai trouvé très pénible et pourtant j'ai tenté de m'y accrocher mais j'ai échoué... >> 07/20

PS : Ceci n'est que mon évaluation, n'hésitez pas à regarder les multiples critiques des autres joueurs et les différentes évaluations car ce titre a reçu de nombreux avis positifs. Achetez en connaissance de cause c'est important :)

L'avis éclairé sur ce soft d'un autre joueur (Attilion) est d'ailleurs intéressant :

"Entre jeu d'exploration/aventure narratif métaconceptuel et pamphlet contre l'industrie du jeu vidéo, The Magic Circle n'est pas fait pour tout le monde, loin de là. Sans appétence pour la programmation (la progression repose sur la capacité de reconfigurer certains éléments de l'environnement) ou pour les discours militants de la part des développeurs (qui ont du subir une ou plusieurs fermetures de studios si on lit entre les lignes), difficile d'y trouver son compte.

En revanche, amateurs de masturbation intellectuelle, un jeu riche, ouvert et varié vous tend les bras. Sans réels éléments scriptés ou objectifs clairs, le jeu est assez peu linéaire et ouvert à l'expérimentation de ses mécaniques, ce qui est plutôt rafraîchissant. Donc, si vous n'êtes pas allergique au côté "indé" un peu caricatural, vous pouvez y aller les yeux fermés pour quelques heures de plaisir."

31286775.review:
[i]"Однажды государственная комиссия заказала [древнегреческому скульптору Поликлету] статую и все время давала советы, что и как должно быть в ней изображено. Поликлет стал делать одновременно две статуи: одну он никому не показывал и делал по своему усмотрению, другую держал на виду и покорно вносил в нее все требуемые поправки. Когда настал срок, он представил комиссии обе статуи на выбор. Комиссия сказала: «Первая статуя прекрасна, а вторая ужасна!» — «Так знайте же, — ответил Поликлет, — первую сделал я, а вторую сделали вы»."[/i]
М.Л. Гаспаров, Занимательная Греция. 

[h1]"Лебедь, рак и щука" в реалиях геймдева[/h1]

Мы играем за тестера, которого нанимает игровая студия, безуспешно пытающаяся закончить работу над продолжением хита двадцатилетней давности. Студия в основном состоит из 3 человек - старый разработчик первого хита Иш, который ревностно оберегает свое творческое видение и ставит сюжет настолько выше геймплея, что, например, полностью вырезает из игры боевую систему только лишь затем, чтобы игроки не могли попытаться убить дружественных NPC (а тех, кто хочет такой возможности, презирает). Мейз, пришедшая в геймдев из про-гейминга манчкинша, полная противоположность Иша, которая считает, что сюжет в играх для галочки, а внимания достойна только боевка. Она собирает коллекцию из воплей побежденных ею в онлайне игроков, любовно называя ее Хором Проклятых, и мечтает уволиться, но не может по бюрократическим причинам. И наконец Кода - фанатка первой части, боготворившая Иша раньше, но разочарованная в его нынешних решениях. Она ценит в игре атмосферность и правдободобность, предлагая, к примеру, добавить NPC действия вроде сна (на что Мейз цинично заявляет: "просто заставь их бесконечно ходить туда-сюда и все"), но больше всего желает, чтобы вторая часть повторяла первую, насколько это возможно. Вместе они тянут разработку в разные стороны, и в итоге у них раз за разом, билд за билдом, ничего не выходит. 

[h1]Горькая ирония с квадратом на обложке[/h1]

Возможно, из этого описания вы сделаете вывод, что это очередной The Stanley Parable, симулятор ходьбы со сломанной четвертой стеной и потоком саркастичных комментариев о природе геймеров от разработчиков. И окажетесь правы - на первые 10 минут. Все меняется, когда с вами напрямую связывается _сама игра_ (вернее, ИИ одного из заброшенных билдов, который обрел самосознание) и просит вас прекратить этот фарс - заставить студию каким-то чудом закончить разработку и отправить игру на золото. Она дает нам возможность менять саму себя изнутри наподобие Pony Island, выискивая уязвимости, восстанавливая удаленные объекты и меняя свойства NPC. И тут можно по-настоящему проявить креативность - хотите создать армию летающих камней, следующих за вами и дышащих огнем на врагов? Пожалуйста. Хотите зомби с лазерной пушкой, лечащего союзников? Вот он. Или, может, робота, заражающего врагов паразитами?.. ну, вы поняли. Задачи в игре, хоть и немногочисленны, решаются уймой способов, а конец, хоть и наступает быстро, одновременно и заставляет задуматься, всегда ли мы поступаем правильно, предъявляя претензии к геймдевам ИРЛ, и открывает новый режим игры, который, честно говоря, оказался очень приятным сюрпризом. Не могу говорить конкретно, ибо спойлеры, но не всякая студия тратила бы время на такое, когда можно было бы обойтись и катсценой.

[h1]Вердикт[/h1]

Я оцениваю эту игру на 9/10 - один балл снят только лишь за то, что игра кончается слишком быстро. Столь необычные игры выходят непростительно редко, и стоило бы растянуть удовольствие хотя бы вдвое... хотя кто я такой, чтобы оспаривать видение разработчиков?

31227809.review:
An enjoyable game, if you can get past the overly preachy tone.  You're in the role of a playtester of a game that's been stuck in development hell for the past 20 years, and with the help of a mysterious "Old Pro" you gain the ability to glitch and alter the game from the inside.  The mix-and-match critters mechanic is great fun; the defining moment for me was hopping onto my pet rock to ride it into battle - my flying, laser-beam-shooting pet rock, that is.  You can bet that "Ride of the Valkyries" was running through my head at the time.  The flamethrower zombie I made earlier was rather funny, too, and then there's the baby...

As others have said, the main game is fairly short, although searching for all the hidden logs can extend it a bit as well as help flesh out the main characters.  So don't go into this expecting some kind of Skyrim-like epic.  But if you manage to catch it on sale it's a fun way to spend an afternoon.

31226670.review: Interesting concept, lets you really be creative and think about how to solve a puzzle your own way. Plus, not a half bad story to boot. All in all, Good Game.

31210491.review: loved it.  very interesting story and fun dynamic gameplay..

31205439.review:
The most sure-fire way of making an Oscar-bait movie is to make a film that has Hollywood and film-making at its core. I’m not sure that in the world of video games, the same principle applies when you make a game about game development, because otherwise, this game would’ve won.

It’s a fun little romp through a satirized version of the turbulent development of a long-anticipated game and you are a beta-tester for this still fairly broken game. It makes fun of games stuck in development hell and constant course corrections over the years (Duke Nukem Forever comes to mind) as well as over-inflated game developer egos with hints towards Richard Garriott and Peter Molyneux and doesn’t stop before also making fun of fanboys and their perceived entitlement of an intellectual property based on their admiration for said intellectual property. 

To say more about the narrative of the game would spoil a lot of the surprises, but I found it highly entertaining. The dialogues are written with tons of levity and it’s clear that it isn’t meant as a scathing critique of any one thing, but more of a lighthearted satire at the expense of how seriously we sometimes take this medium. But what really brings the script together is the fantastic voice-acting from all the characters.

Gameplaywise it continues the theme of game development, with you traversing an unfinished world filled with hostile creatures that you yourself can’t fight because the designer opted to remove the combat altogether right when you start playing. But you’re given the ability to manipulate the game world itself through a very simplistic form of changing the source code. You’re able to undelete things since garbage collection apparently hasn’t been implemented yet and you can retool properties and variables of objects and creatures, turning enemies into allies and giving them a variety of different abilities with tons of creative potential with all the available combinations. It’s not a very deep system and there isn’t a ton of finesse to it, but there are a few puzzles you need to solve with this mechanic. 

If there’s one thing that bothered me about the game it was the final stretch where you are tasked to create a “level” of this fictional game yourself. You don’t really need to put any thought into it, but it’s really the low-point of the game for me, since it takes just a little bit too long and the punchline to that particular part of the game isn’t the funniest. The game is also fairly short. You can beat it in as little as two hours if you don’t go out of your way of collecting the “developer” commentaries and notes which only serve to provide some additional humor and I’m not entirely convinced that it deserves the $20 price tag, but I still have to praise the game for being primarily focused on a narrative and theme while still managing to provide the player with interesting if not massively rewarding gameplay and not just a walking simulator, so I’d definitely recommend it at a discount.

31031322.review:
This game sat on my wishlist for a year or so after I first played the demo, and after finally getting to play it, I am very satisfied. The Magic Circle might not be very long (I have about 4 hours of playtime on record to finish), or mind-blowing in any way, but it is, in fact, incredibly unique. The mechanics are interesting, the story was good, and there was even some puzzles in there that I didn't really expect.

Pros:
+ The story. This is a game about game devs working on a twenty-year long video game project with an "auteur" who won't allow his "vision" to get tampered with by his former pro-gamer coworker and their spunky intern. You are a playtester who starts mucking around in the code and...
+ The mechanics: ...bringing back formerly "deleted" enemies and scenery and stealing attributes like fire attacks, and adding yourself to its list of allies. I made a mushroom hop around and a key breathe fire. By the end, I had a horde of allies following me around and fighting my battles.
+ Meta-humor. Tons of references about game development hell, with things like a DOOM-esque sci-fi area that you can explore (complete with pixely goodness) from an abandoned version of the game, game devs arguing about how the player can beat the final battle without a sword, storyboards and sketches, notes from the devs about unfinished levels, etc.
+ Puzzles. There was definitely more of a puzzle aspect than I suspected after playing the demo! Pleasant surprise!
+ Secrets to find. Hidden bits of story, upgrades for your minions.

Neutral:
~ There are basically two sections to the game: 1) A big open, interconnected world with lots of different areas and unlockable upgrades, story points, enemies to edit or fight. This was the main game and it was incredibly fun, but then... 2) There's a "level designer" bit, where you have to design a level with a good difficulty level and interest curve for another character to play through in order to finish the story. This was not quite as fun for me because it felt tedious, and a definite shift in the game's mechanics. You could still edit enemies, but there wasn't any skill to it. Basically, you set up the level, have the character playtest it, then debug it so it doesn't kill or bore him.

Cons:
- Length. I could have done with a little longer gameplay, more areas to explore and more baddies. Overall, I was pretty satisfied with my play experience, but for some people (especially at full price), it might feel too short.

Overall: Very fun and unique, interesting mechanics. 9/10.

30519810.review:
The Magic Circle is a first-person exploration/puzzle game. It's unique to me for a few reasons:

1) The premise of the game is subverting an in-game game. But the path isn't linear or obvious - one of my favorite moments is when a character says they won't help you so you can come up with your own creative sabotage.

2) There's a pretty rich story. Sometimes it distracted from the gameplay, but the characters are strong and you get to know them well.

3) They got the talented Stephen Russell as a primary voice actor (the gravely voice in the trailer). He's a fan-favorite from Thief 1 & 2, Skyrim, Fallout 4, and others. His performance was excellent, and I found myself playing past the ending to find more of his dialgoue. Ken Levine also has a cameo role, and it's pretty cool that they got these two in the same game.

The premise and gameplay of The Magic Circle are fresh and creative. Give it a go!

28773111.review:
Yet another unfinished, buggy, poorly-made Early Access game which will likely never be finished... this is not. However, it is still presetning itself as one.

This may be the story of a broken, unfinished game. But the game which you play, the game about that game, is most certainly neither of these things.

Instead, it is a clever, charming puzzle game, in which every puzzle has no solution. No formal solution, at least, because the in-game dev characters haven't gotten around to finishing them.

However, with the tools you have at your disposal, it is possible to MacGyver yourself not just one, but a number of potential solutions to each obstacle. And that, in my opinion, paves the way for the greatest part of this game: the social aspect.

Sure, it feels great to come up with a clever way of traversing one of the puzzles. But it feels even better to then tell a friend your solution, only to find out that they never thought of using that method, and instead used some elaborate ticks of their own which you had never thought of.

And even without a friend who also plays this game, I can guarantee that anyone going through this game's story a second time will likely solve a number of puzzles a different way the second time around than they did the first.

28513500.review:
[h1]Development hell изнутри[/h1]
   Говорят, что разработку игры - как и ремонт - невозможно закончить. Можно только прекратить. The Magic Circle рассказывает об игровом проекте, который застрял на этапе производства так долго, что уже пережил несколько глобальных ревизий, вырос из своей эпохи и до смерти надоел создателям.
   Здесь все ненавидят всех. Сценаристы грызутся с программистами, у тестеров есть серьезные вопросы к моделлерам, и все вместе они безумно устали от причуд ведущего геймдизайнера. За все время успело вырасти целое [i]поколение[/i], которое влилось в этот беспощадный конвейер!
   Что ж, растеряв всю команду, тимлид плюнул на имеющиеся наработки и решительно двинулся к следующему проекту. Уж с ним все однозначно получится - и общественная поддержка вернется, и спонсоры заинтересуются, и наконец-то можно будет рассказать Ту Самую историю на новом движке.
   Но... как же старая игра? А вот так: протагонист, освобожденный от надзора создателей и брошенный на произвол судьбы, фактически получил весь мир игры в свое распоряжение. Заручившись поддержкой Old Pro (реликта еще более старой разработки), мы начинаем подминать правила под себя. 

[h1]Армия миньонов[/h1]
   В действительности все не так уж весело и смело, как манят описания. Игрок никогда не обретает полноценного контроля, побаловаться с режимом бога дают на две минуты в самом конце, а до тех пор наше взаимодействие с миром сводится к охоте на "свойства" мобов и их применению в паззлах. Алгоритм такой: найти новое существо с полезной характеристикой (атака, электричество, огонь, полет и так далее), потом захватить или убить его, потом добавить свойство в свою коллекцию. Смыть, повторить. 
   С пополнением "зоопарка" становятся доступны новые области карты, а значит, новые свойства и новые секреты. Иногда - очки прокачки, иногда - записки и аудилоги, проливающие свет на все эти закулисные интриги. Существенная часть контента абсолютно опциональна и не дает ничего кроме ачивок и, может, необычных прислужников в свиту. Даже прокачка не играет особой роли, поскольку эпических сражений прислужников в игре не предусмотрено. А жаль.
   Разворачивается все в предельно минималистичном антураже, что объясняется выбранной стилистикой для игры-в-игре, хотя этим можно все что угодно объяснить. Но дизайн мил, озвучка убедительна, а взаимные перепалки разработчиков отчаянно хороши. Под конец припасен еще один бонус (уже получается, игра-в-игре-в-игре), подводящий удовлетворительный итог усилиям всех действующих лиц. В общем, интересно.
   Далее последуют небольшие спойлеры и мои обычные субъективные рассуждения.

[h1]Эндгейм, спойлеры, нытье[/h1]
   Чем дальше в игру, тем больше раскрывалась личность ведущего геймдизайнера как художественного персонажа. Это логично и хорошо, но вместе с этим менялся тон повествования. Вместо забавностей из трудовых будней разработчиков - личностная драма. Вместо веселых обменов колкостями - скандалы и грязь. Повторюсь, все это крайне субъективно, но игра шла куда легче, когда показывала разницу восприятия игры между "творцами" и "ремесленниками", чем когда начались откровения про творческий кризис, наследие и бесплодие. Йеп, именно бесплодие - в биологическом смысле. И как-то уже неловко присутствовать при всем этом, будто случайно подслушал личный разговор, явно для твоих ушей не предназначенный.
   Я думаю, что The Magic Circle как реальная игра в стиме не лишена многих недостатков "The Magic Circle" как выдуманной игры. Ограниченность в одних геймплейных аспектах и избыточность в других, пустой мир, слабость графики и сюжета, частая смена фокуса - как тут понять, что делалось сознательно, а что просто "не получилось"? Как понять, где разработчики остроумно поддразнивают меня, а где решили тихонечко схалтурить, уверенные, что грань уже слишком размыта?
   Но, если честно, я проживу и без этого знания.

28485063.review:
The Magic Circle is an immaculate game where you delve into the depths of an unfinished game. You, the player are tasked with testing a game that has been stuck in development hell, however the game is nowhere near finished regardless of the multitude of years spent in development. Along your way you stumble across a being who has been stuck within the game since its inception, trapped and alone, the developers indifferent to his existence. You are given the power to shape and mold the creatures as you see fit, outfitting them with different features from various other entities within the game. 

This game is well worth your time, with its fantastic story direction, and overall freedom to accomplish tasks as you please. If you've "seen it all" from the game industry, this game is for you.

Pros: 

- Freedom of progression, as well as freedom to accomplish tasks in any way you see fit.

- The innate lack of a combat system for yourself, forcing you to rely upon the creatures you encounter along the way to protect you. 

- Mold the games creatures any way you like to accomplish any task. Take features from specific creatures, and add them to your personal collection of modifications you can apply to anything at any time. Do you want a turtle that has a teleportation pad on its back? YOU GOT IT.

- Fantastic Story Direction, with a twist at the end I wasn't expecting whatsoever.

- Fantastic soundtrack, which made me feel as though I was actually within the game, controlling everything myself.

- Simple collectibles system.

- Return to the game world after completing the game to allow for completionists to find any missed collectibles.


Cons: 

- Short game. For the price point of $20, the game is incredibly short, spanning about 5-7 hours, whilst they are incredibly enjoyable, it is a tad much for the game.

- There is an issue of glitching through the game, as well as glitching into specific objects at certain intervals.

- Clunky movement system, wherein the player hitbox seems larger than the player himself.


Overall: I would recommend this game to anyone I know, due to its completely unconventional nature in that you are the one to shape the game world and bend it to your very will.

[h1]Disclaimers - [/h1]
Played for about 30 minutes as part of my [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLsd4qfq-hrCyqiN6rpMVLVvLQafPZqv2e] Let's Play My Steam Library[/url] playlist for my Youtube channel. Check out the video: [url=https://youtu.be/cveOKFJXXm4] https://youtu.be/cveOKFJXXm4[/url]

[h1]tl;dr - [/h1]
Absolutely wonderful game with a brilliant story and fantastic game mechanics. If you like meta humor, you'll love this. Art style is magnificent and complements the story perfectly. Definitely must play this.

[h1]ATTN: PARENTS - [/h1] 
[u]NOT recommended for young children.[/u] Contains...
Scenes of violent death with blood - if a bit graphically non-realistic, still poignant.
[h1]Clarifying Info[/h1] 
This is definitely a game. Not just a simulation of a game. But a real game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1] 
Such awesome mechanics! They feel fleshed out and well executed. Very excited to play this one through. Controls are on point - no complaints.
[h1]Sound[/h1] 
No complaints about the sound either. Very nice, and fits the story well.
[h1]Visuals[/h1] 
I absolutely love the unfinished art style of this game. And the color effects as you gain life - so awesome. Such a fantastic job!
[h1]Story[/h1] 
And then this... If the other items above were great, this part is phenomenal. If you like meta humor and video games, you will love this story. I was laughing from the beginning. Great humor and such a wonderful way to introduce a story.
[h1]Characters[/h1] 
This goes with the story - so freaking awesome! Very well done.
[h1]Safe for Kids?[/h1]
There is some darker humor. But mostly I would worry about the violence and death. That's probably what would stop a parent from letting their child play this. Right?
[h1]Rating[/h1]
[strike]1- don't buy; don't waste your time[/strike]
[strike]2- buy only when on a great sale (75% off or <$5)[/strike]
[strike]3- you should give it a shot; buy it on sale; if you like this genre[/strike]
[strike]4- definitely play this game[/strike]
[h1][b]5- AWESOME - absolutely must play![/b][/h1]

28185479.review:
A cautious recommendation mostly because of the length - you'll get about two hours playing normally and [i]maybe[/i] three and a half going for all of the secrets. Some games can definitely justify $20 for that length, I think this one has too weak of a final third and too much empty space to be among them. Buy on sale. 

The Magic Circle is a meta-game about being some kind of ghost/beta tester in a game trapped in development hell. The story is mostly told through the clashes between a developer who is too visionary for his own good, a rabid fangirl of the sort that sends death threats over delays, and a pro gamer contract-locked into a heavily narrative game despite opposing narratives in games. The dynamic is interesting, but only a few moments of the story are ultimately memorable. 

Gameplay consists of trapping and (visually) reprogamming enemies with traits stolen from other creatures and objects. There's no limit on how many followers you can create through this method, and the stupidity you can cause with it is absolutely the highlight of the game. Combat is mostly trivialized by your army of death, but there are a few environmental puzzles that require you to combine traits in creative ways. Unfortunately, this system disappears almost entirely in the last third. 

I can't get too much into why I disliked the ending moments without heavy spoilers, but suffice to say it throws out all of the good gameplay and replaces it with something that's just tedious. That said, the sequence right before this does at least manage a few good laughs. 

It has its moments and isn't at all a bad way to spend two hours, but it's not one you're going to be thinking back to in a year.

Questo titolo non è riuscito a prendermi per nulla.
Nonostante io apprezzi tantissimo i progetti videoludici aticipi (alla The Stanley Parable e simili), The Magic Circle non è riuscito a convincermi.
L'impatto iniziale è stato positivo, grazie allo stile grafico adottato (sembra quasi un fumetto) e alle battute e frecciatine che i personaggi narranti si scambiano fin dal principio.

Il nostro scopo è finire un videogioco incompleto, principalmente modificando alcune creature facenti parti del mondo circostante a nostro piacimento (cambiando le skill, la possibilità di movimento, di attacco), risolvendo in tal modo piccoli puzzle.

Purtroppo è proprio sul gameplay che mi ha delusa, in quanto svanito l'entusiasmo inziale mi sono ritrovata in un'esperienza di gioco abbastanza noiosa.
E' sicuramente un titolo particolare del quale premio l'originalità e il concept, ma non ne ho apprezzato il gameplay come avrei voluto.

26974988.review:
The Magic Circle é o primeiro projeto da Question Games, empresa criada por Stephen Alexander e Jordan Thomas, profissionais que participaram da criação de todos os jogos da série Bioshock, até o Infinite. Além deles, faz parte do time Kain Shain, responsável pela inteligência artificial de Dishonored.

Ou seja, temos aqui caras experientes na indústria de jogos, que resolveram abandonar o desenvolvimento de jogos AAA e buscam criar outros tipos de conteúdo, no cenário independente. E devo dizer que eles começaram com o pé direito.

A primeira coisa que você faz ao entrar no jogo é entrar no jogo. Com uma bela quebra da quarta parede logo na primeira cena, seu trabalho, como jogador, é testar o título de fantasia medieval em primeira pessoa The Magic Circle, que está há 20 anos em desenvolvimento. O plano é fechar ao menos uma demo jogável para o público, que há tempos clama pela nova obra de Ishamel Gilder, desenvolvedor do projeto, e que se tornou cultuado após o sucesso de sua primeira criação, um adventure.

Não demora para você perceber que falta muito para aquilo se tornar um jogo de fato. Gráficos inacabados, gambiarras de game design e mesmo itens ausentes, não programados, são rapidamente encontrados. Tudo isso enquanto Ish vai discutindo os próximos passos do projeto com Maze Evelyn, desenvolvedora, que já está perdendo as esperanças em tudo isso, e Coda Soliz, assistente novata, que é fanática pelo trabalho de Gilder.


Pouco tempo depois, o jogo acaba. E então, ele começa de novo. Após finalizar seu trabalho, uma espécie de inteligência artificial faz você voltar para o protótipo. Essa entidade é um resquício da primeira versão de The Magic Circle, que originalmente seria um FPS no espaço. Ela clama por sua ajuda para, de dentro do próprio jogo, tentar terminá-lo. Ou então acabar com esse sofrimento de uma vez.

Nessa nova empreitada, você ganha habilidades para hackear e “quebrar” o jogo, de forma a moldá-lo de uma maneira que você consiga resolver os puzzles e concluir sua tarefa. Uma dessas formas de manipulação é a habilidade de editar NPCs. Você pode, literalmente, entrar na programação de um monstro e alterar coisas como forma de movimentação, habilidades especiais (resistência ao fogo, por exemplo), definir NPCs inimigos e aliados. Criar um cogumelo voador com um lança-chamas como aliado é uma das inúmeras possibilidades que você tem.

Durante sua jornada, você irá se deparar com os desenvolvedores (no formato de grandes olhos). Às vezes eles se dirigem a você diretamente, outras, estão falando entre si. Em ambos os casos, o jogador começa a notar como um processo de desenvolvimento tão caótico os afeta.

Lidar com outras pessoas, ideias diferentes e problemas pessoais é constante no mundo de trabalho. Não seria diferente no desenvolvimento de um jogo, algo que algumas pessoas pensam ser mágico e maravilhoso.

São nesses diálogos, aliados a outros arquivos de áudio e texto espalhados pelo mapa, que está a força de The Magic Circle. Com um humor muito bem construído, ele pode ser visto como uma crítica à indústria, na sua forma de pensar e lidar com seu público. E mesmo na resposta do público, que pode ser cruel e devastadora.

A história vai progredindo dessa maneira, pouco a pouco, lhe dando peças do que está acontecendo. Tudo isso culmina com um encerramento que não poderia ter sido executado de melhor forma. Talvez você só ache engraçado, talvez você pare para pensar um pouco como enxerga videogames. Mas tenho certeza que indiferente você não vai ficar.

A parte gráfica de The Magic Circle pode soar estranha para algum desavisado. Digo isso, pois há uma mistura de conceitos e mesmo algumas coisas fora de lugar. Mas tudo isso é proposital. A mistura de elementos e as mudanças repentinas de estilo são executadas com esmero.

A trilha sonora também é de extrema qualidade, dando o clima perfeito para todos os momentos do jogo. A dublagem também é destaque, e dá vida a todos os personagens que aparecem na trama.

Por fim, vale citar que é um jogo bem curto — mesmo enrolado em algumas partes, 4 horas foram suficientes para terminá-lo. Mas isso, nem de longe é um problema. Pelo contrário, ele tem a medida certa para contar o que precisa ser contado.

Existem colecionáveis, que são os arquivos de áudio e video que mencionei anteriormente. Explorando bem, dá para pegar a maioria, sem muitas dificuldades, já no primeiro playthrough.

Quando peguei The Magic Circle para fazer sua análise, apenas havia visto um trailer e pensado comigo mesmo, “deve ser só mais um joguinho meio pirado com algumas piadas nonsense”. Pois bem, fico feliz por ter errado, e descoberto que ele não é só isso.

The Magic Circle é um belo exercício da metalinguagem, que critica e faz piadas com a indústria de jogos tocando em pontos importantes, às vezes esquecidos: quem são as pessoas por trás dos títulos que tanto amamos? Que histórias pessoais estão por de trás da construção de novos jogos? Quais direitos nós, jogadores, temos em cima de obras de outros, se é que temos algum?

Além de um enredo muito interessante, o título traz mecânicas peculiares, que dão ao jogador uma liberdade diferente do que é comumente encontrado, abrindo possibilidades promissoras.

Talvez seu único problema seja a falta de localização para o português, o que pode afastar da obra quem não domina a língua inglesa — e para The Magic Circle, compreender a história é essencial. O jogo também possui legendas em francês, italiano, alemão e espanhol.

26459398.review:
You play like an alpha tester for a game in progress, although obviously more fun than the real life equivalent. Instead of looking for bugs, documenting and making repeatable cases, etc. you just do whatever you want and explore an unfinished open world. You don't really look for bugs but you're often rewarded with story logs if you explore places you're not 'supposed' to get to.

The developers are basically gods that can change the game world at an instant and at their whim. And while Ish especially has many whims, there were times during game development that others (for better or worse) helped stagnate development.

Story was fun, discovering what happened in the past via audio logs was nice, music was nice, visuals were (intentionally at times) mediocre. I felt most of the overworld graphics were suitable to the game; black and white made it feel like sketch work. But sometimes in other areas the graphics were intentionally so old it figuratively hurt me to play through all the jagged lines and low res graphics. But even the overworld graphics/assets, if colored and used in a proper game, would look very mediocre by today's standards.

The big draw in gameplay for me is that you get to change attributes on creatures/objects you find in the game. Each creature has its own properties (like movement: ground, attack: melee, special ability: fireproof, ally: hero, enemy: none). You can take these properties and then place it on other objects. So you can take a rock and make it mobile, your ally (so it follows you as a pet), and attack with flames.

You do so much walking in this game that it really would be nice for a run/sprint button even if momentum didn't carry over to jumps. I would have liked to move faster, jump length wasn't really a problem.

Other thoughts:
[*] Finding new ways of getting around the world is pretty important. I went from walking to [spoiler]Minecraft ender pearling[/spoiler] to [spoiler]magic carpeting[/spoiler].
[*] It would have been nice to have separate non-subtitle and substitle language controls (as someone who likes to mix them).
[*] I lost an ability when I met [spoiler]Cerebra. Cerebra mindswapped the corpse then the corpse mindswapped my cyber-rat with the lightning rod ability. The corpse died and I couldn't find it. And then when I went to the 'final boss' and died, the corpse with lightning rod showed up next to me when I respawned even though I never had access to editing it before. It wasn't summoned before the boss (using LMB+RMB) but just appeared afterwards.[/spoiler]
[*] It keeps track of creatures edited, so if you want to 100% that stat you need to keep an eye out. I ignored duplicates of certain things on my run because I wasn't aware of that stat and there was no real reason to do so.
[*] You can clip through certain things and get stuck or fall out of the world. Luckily the game allows you to teleport to certain locations on the map.
[/list]

Worth a try if you like the idea of a pseudo-programming/game dev game. I'm not aware of another game that plays this angle with this gameplay.

To be honest, I wanted more from the game. I was hoping that eventually you could edit your own properties. I only found 7 actions/attacks to choose from and 5 special properties. It's a decent amount because they're very distinct (no ice beam vs fire beam) but not quite satisfying if you want a sandbox. But even then, you don't really find a place that you need to use all of them. It's really just enough to get through the story.

26350237.review: It's a reasonably interesting meta-game, 6 hours long. I found it a lot more interesting than A Beginner's Guide. There's not much I can tell you that you can't already see in the trailer - it's a game about picking apart a game from the inside while figuring out how its development went so wrong.

26072721.review:
Rating: 8/10
Overview: First Person Exploration/Puzzle

The Good:

+ The entire premise is breaking down the 4th wall between 'game' and 'player'. You play as an intern tester inside of a game stuck in development hell. 

+ The gameplay is also designed around that same premise. You have the ability to hack/edit enemies, take their abilities, add them to others and turning them into your allies. Mixing and matching abilities is cool and creates a lot of different possibilities in how you approach a puzzle. 

+ After completing the game I saw some videos, went online and discovered multiple ways of completing the game that I had never even though of. The fact that there are multiple ways of solving puzzles in many creative ways is really cool. 

+ The game features a mish mash of different art styles to reflect the poor state of the game. 


The Average:

The story/dialogue is compromised mostly of the developers arguing about what the game should be and what features should be in it. I felt the story get a bit strange given the satirical nature of the game and a lot of the humor can be hit or miss.  I wasn't too fond of the characters. 

Somewhat short, clocking in around 2-3 hours depending on how much you do or how fast you solve the puzzles. This can be extended by going after all the collectables. 

Conclusion

A fun game about how not to make a game. I thought a lot of the ideas were very creative and the themes presented shed some light on the current state of the video game industry while never taking itself too seriously. The concept of mixing different abilities for your allies is really neat, an idea that can easily be explored in other games. A fun if not distracting game while it lasts.

25987696.review:
Very very good.  Well written, funny, and with some pretty interesting gameplay.  I was honestly expecting this to be a walking simulator and it's not. 

The best way I can describe this game is that it's a combination of The Stanely Parable, The Beginner's Guide, Double Fine's Hack 'n' Slash, and Overlord/Pikmen.  

Gameplay consists of rewriting enemies and objects codes and turning them, effectively, into your minions.  Those minions do the combat for you, and there are a couple of puzzles involving these mechanics.  It's very well done.  

The writing itself is very good.  It manages to make all of the characters sympathetic, despite them all being awful people.  That's not easy to do, so it's very well done.  

I would absolutely recommend this.
