15875664.review:
If you enjoy games such as Antichamber, Stanley Parable, and/or Bioshock I think you’ll like this. It emphasizes exploration more than puzzles or combat, but I think it’s somewhere in that range. Very refreshing and very worth your time.

I’d been excited to play this because of Jordan Thomas’s involvement (Shalebridge Cradle, Fort Frolic), but otherwise didn’t know what to expect.

The first surprise is that it’s the funniest game he’s worked on. The narrative is mostly delivered by overhearing conversations, sort of a comedy radio play. The characters are exaggerated blends of some well-known developers (Richard “Lord British” Garriott, John Romero, Warren Spector, Stevie Case, etc.). Some characters talk directly to you, but since you are involved in the fiction as a ‘player’ it frequently makes jokes as it breaks the 4th wall. The world contains a huge number visual gags about unfinished/buggy/cliché games and these are funny as long as you’ve looked at a level editor or bad game even once. There’s also text logs that poke fun at the petty disagreements that happen when developing a game.

The second surprise (though more in tune with Jordan’s other work) is that it’s really creepy. Everything in the game’s presentation is trying to unsettle you. The world looks like it’s barely held together and every action you take looks breaks the world just a little more, almost to the point of snapping in two. There’s layers of subtext anywhere you look and it’s like snooping in someone’s trash. The motivations and origins of characters are mysterious enough to draw you in and push your comfort level as you voyeuristically hear their interactions.

The third surprise is the actual gameplay. It’s hard to tell if this is a FPS, RPG, or what from the trailer (or even the first hour of play). It finally hit me that the easiest description is that it’s a necromancer game with some light puzzle elements. It’s presented as an open world, but some directions are blocked off until you find a decent combination of ‘spells’ to open up a new path. The necromancy also plays into the creepiness since your army of the undead is kind of a loud menace that won’t give you personal space.

The final section of the game goes in some crazy directions with story and gameplay. It’s a little too much to take in as one big chunk, but it’s also a great climax that makes the game feel complete. It’s a nice self-contained story and I can’t fault for being a bit meta or navel gazing when it’s so unlike anything else I’ve played before.

15857909.review: Heartfelt, full of dark comedy as well as some thought provoking moments, this is one of those rare games you kinda wish was longer, or would get a sequel...but the more you think about it, the more you realize it's perfect the way it is.

15857862.review:
For anyone who is a fan of game design, this is a sometimes funny, sometimes fascinating, sometimes all-to-real look at the behind the scenes of making a video game.   The first half is part adventure game, part first-person exploration, with lots of secrets to discover.  Any player who has tried exploring "outside the box" will definitely enjoy every moment of this part of the game.   The second half is so completely different and unique that it actually constitutes a spoiler even to tell you what it is.  Just be assured that if you liked the plot and dialogue in the first half, you'll love the second half.
... 
After a second playthrough, and completing nearly all content, I have to mention the one real drawback to this game: It's short.  Like, really short.  A complete playthrough can run less than 5 hours, and that's listening to all the dialogue, exploring all the spaces.   I personally believe that the price was worth it, but I know most people are going to balk at $20 for 5 hours of gameplay (especially since it's probably not something most people would play more than once).

15833003.review:
I went out on a limb for this game, given its background, i trusted it. Made by the Bioshock 2 director, The Magic Circle is an open-world puzzle game that doesn't leave you out to dry like many Metroid fans would like you to think you want. 

Through a series of events, you are able to manipulate items and monsters around you, and swap traits. Want a pet rock that can stab things? No prob.

This game puts YOU in control of how you want to do things, as there are an infinite number of ways to compete things. Coupled with JUST enough push in the right direction to not have you screaming "WHAT DO I DO, WHERE DO I GO?!"

I beat it in one long sitting, however there is an actual extensive THING at the end that is full of replayability (that i won't spoil for obvious reasons). This game had many surprises and even mixes up the gameplay a few times.

Was it worth the money? Absolutely. This game reminds me a lot of Tiny and Big in Grandpa's Leftovers, another shortish, but very appealing game with a unique gameplay style.

I tried not to spoil too much, so what are you waiting for? GO PLAY

15816526.review:
This is an Early Access review of The Magic Circle! Be warned that I do not like Early Access because of how many projects that never get finished!

Welcome, one and all, the The Magic Circle. Welcome to a land where gametesters are gods and the designers are lazy. 

The Magic Circle is a very innovative and creative first person adventure game. You begin by starting the game with nothing in hand and the creators of the virtual world talking in the background. The game is a strange one. Imagine The Stanley Parable mixed with Portal; even though it's not like either of those games in the slightest. For some strange reason, the game reminded me of those two games in many ways. 

Your character has no name and you don't have any weapons, even though this is an RPG... an unfinished one (on purpose, it's part of the game's charm). The game has beautiful graphics from every era along with colorful characters and gameplay! 

Pros:
+Beautiful graphics style
+Original gameplay and story
+Unique artstyle
+Lots of 4th wall breaks
+Original UI for upgrades and inventory
+Amazing voice acting

Cons:
+Graphical errors (such as me being able to look through walls/ floors in certain places)

The game isn't a short one. If you're expecting a short and sweet Early Access indie, then you are mistaken. The game is very polished and has amazing voice acting. This hidden Steam gem should be known by everyone. I can't wait to see what the developers have in store for the full release!

I'd give this game a 9/10. I will gladly add the single point back when the graphical mishaps are corrected.

Amazing job guys, I'm impressed!

40933720.review:
Verdict: 6/10 TMC provides innovative game mechanics in a rotten package. 


[b]Spoilers in this review![/b]

The Magic Circle is a game with meta jokes and gameplay like the Stanley Parable but the story it provides is weak and the game is an ugly uncomfortable experience.
That being said, I almost recommend this game because of the 1 clever gimmick it provides that makes it fun. 

[b]Editing the Game World (the gimmick): [/b]
	You can edit the characteristics of enemies! That's pretty cool! You edit the way they move, attack, what they attack. and who they follow.
	The best part of this feature is that the models of the characters actually change in pretty clever ways. 
	Movement by flight adds propellers, ground can add legs, special attacks give each model a unique component physically added. 
	Its clear some care went into this aspect of the game, and it works really well. 
	Amassing armies of allies was a blast and tuning them to tackle each puzzle was fun.

[b]The Story:[/b]
	The plot is a bit psychotic. I tried to care about the plot but it was too on the nose and ultimately just...weird, none of the characters are likeable.
	Stanley Parable had some subtlety to it and discovering each ending was a fresh and fruitful experience. The story in TMC is obvious and gets old quick.
	After completing the game [spoiler] you get to use a level editor which runs on similar mechanics to the main gameplay. Utilizing a "Bored" meter your levels are playtested by the AI  with verbal feedback.[/spoiler]

[b]UI: [/b]
	The UI is pretty clunky and I had a lot of issues with cursor offset.
	The entire playthrough I experienced a bug that would cause me to walk backwards at random times, maybe this was due to my attached peripherals but it was very annoying.
	The environment and graphics are nauseating and hard on the eyes. The world is also very open, but small in size and lacks direction at times.

40901719.review: I really enjoyed this game! It has a very unique style that I haven't seen in other games. Although I played through it in 11 hours, it kept surprising me with new things to do. Hearing the interaction between the "gods" was pretty entertaining as well. Highly recommended.

From being able to give a teleporter legs to making a flying baby that shoots flames, I can't get enough. The art is beautiful, abstract and fit for this title. 40761134.review:
I'd say its worth 3 [i]Evolands[/i], or 0.9 [i]Stanley Parables[/i]

A unique take on game development and general artistic vision. The story focuses around the creation of a hotly anticipated  video game and looks into how the expectations of both the creators and the audience have affected development. There's some well thought out and very cutting statements about players and creators towards the end of the game which elevate [i]The Magic Circle[/i] above its mechanics.

The gameplay mainly centres on rewriting parts of the game's world to your advantage. There's some interesting possibilities with the mechanics but its rather underdeveloped and can sometimes feel cluttered as you accumulate allied units. But that's not the focus of the game, and for all I know it may have been another poke at the barebones design of 2000's PC games.

40436382.review:
Like The Beginner's Guide, The Magic Circle touches on game development and explores the relationships creators can have with their works, but its approach toward and treatment of the subject matter is decidedly different. Instead of a guided tour of a disparate collection of tiny games with little direct interaction, players take on the role of a tester playing The Magic Circle, an in-fiction remake of an acclaimed vintage text adventure that is plagued by scope creep and stuck in development hell as its creators struggle to deal with their personal and interpersonal issues.

A mysterious character within the game guides players towards "hacking" enemies and objects to collect, swap/combine their characteristics and abilities in order to solve puzzles and "finish the game" when its distracted developers could not.

For the most part, players are free to roam and explore The Magic Circle's environments at their own pace and without distraction. The presence of the game's creators doesn't come across as overbearing. They enter, say their pieces, and then leave the player to progress onward, with a lot of context provided through optional in-fiction "commentary nodes" and notes left by the in-fiction lead level designer.

There's a lot within The Magic Circle that's poignant and thoughtful. It feels like it wants to encourage players to understand the demons that creators must wrestle with, and perhaps to consider what it would be like to make a game themselves. The plot has the hallmarks of a tragedy, but at the same time there's something uplifting about it.

The Magic Circle resonated strongly with me, and I'm super glad to have played a small role in helping out with resolving a couple of issues blocking the Linux release.

[i]This was originally written as part of [url=http://cheesetalks.net/gamesRoundup2015.php]a retrospective[/url] on games I finished in 2015.[/i]

40370076.review: I came in expecting something like Antichamber. This isn't quite that, but it is a fun little game with some interesting turns. doesn't overstay its welcome.

this game is honestly amazing

40012331.review:
I'll recommend but I have really mixed opinions on this one.  It honestly feels like a game that got in the way of the story it wanted to tell.  The gimmick is that the game is unfinished, but even as satire, even as the core mechanic, does it help knowing it's intentional?  There are some interesting ideas here, and I'll be damned if the presentation isn't top notch, but the question of whether or not it's worth it to slog through uninteresting gameplay for the sake of an interesting story has always been a no for me.  It's a walking simulator/point-and-click adventure game where rather than specific items, you need to find specific abilities to pass obstacles.  The game tells you not to worry about an 'intended' path but in my experience there ought to be one for obvious reasons, and therefore it's probably easiest to just do that.  The game feels like the story describes it: unfinished and careless.  That sort of makes puzzle solving unenjoyable.

I want to like this one more than I do.  It reminds me of Evoland: the gimmick is interesting, but grows cold before the game ends.  The story is honestly good, but I'm afraid I don't want to trot it's world to see it.  If you want a casual experience with a great story and are pleased just looking around you'll probably like this.  That's why I recommend, some people like this more than me and I appreciate it exists.  But for me, it just isn't enough.

39662209.review:
There's a handful of games that I've played over the years where I've gone in blind, and been glad that I did, because no review could have done it justice. This is one of those games, so if you're at all amenable to the idea, stop reading and just play this now.

If you *insist* on more information: it's a first-person puzzle game, with the unusual feature that most situations can be solved in many different ways by creatively combining abilities. They even say quite early on, if you feel like you're cheating, you're doing it right. It's fun.

The writing is the real treat though - a warm, personal narrative about people in the video games industry. It's backed up by gorgeous but deliberately janky and retro graphics. This is, like The Stanley Parable and Dr Langeskov (...), a video game about video games.
